cinder/volume/drivers/hpe/hpe_3par_iscsi.message: I wasn't sure about this being the appropriate exception, but looks like hpe_3par_base calls this method inside its do_setup() call. cinder/volume/manager.py calls do_setup inside of _init_host() and catches any raised exception, which will log an exception that the driver could not be initialized and return. That will result in self.driver.initialized never being set to true, which unfortunately will cause retries in the initialization, but no way around that and not much harm really.
I agree with Sean, it's not great, and I think we need some kind of unrecoverable error mechanism that allows Cinder to exit, but that's definitely out of the scope of this patch.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/602432/
IIRC ovsdb is supposed to be a native JSON DB. Have you tried passing the data structure to ovsdb, leaving the serialization to it? Maybe it can do actually do that for us.
While writing the ovs-agent side of this I played around with ovsdbapp and I found that we probably cannot pass the data structure itself. We have to serialize it here.

Transactionality is hard in ovsdb. You don't have BEGIN-COMMIT type transactions, but pre-defined command-chain type transactions. With that you can do compare-and-swap I think, but I'm not sure if it's worth it.

I also realized that db_set() has different semantics than I (and likely you too) expected. When you set map values it merges the map passed with the pre-existing map. Therefore you have atomic update in a single db_set().

So instead of get(), add(k, v), set() we can just call set(k, v).

it's better to have a function in osprofiler to store a context into dict (so avoid knowing details here); the similar to serialization into HTTP headers https://opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler/src/branch/master/osprofiler/web.py#L35

if we do that we need to at least add osprofiler to the test requirements. we technically should do that in in anway case. ideally we would add a functional test to validate that this is infact added to ovs in addtion to a basic unit test to assert that db_get/db_set were called

When this is happening?

All OVS vif plug operations (generic, windows, vhost, vf) create a VIF port in the OVS DB. IMO, this should be the place to store this osprofiler information. The OVS agent can retrieve (and delete) this information.

IMO, this should be in external_ids of port Interface [1]

Am I missing something here?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/master/vif_plug_ovs/ovsdb/ovsdb_lib.py#L86-L90

Gibi is on vacation till early August, but we are working on this together so let me answer.

I think we fully agree it would be better to store the trace info as an external_id of the port, not the bridge. However the way we currently use libvirt (i.e. when the interface_type is bridge in the libvirt domain definition) it always deletes and re-creates the ovs port. IIRC this is the relevant piece of code:

https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/3f7cba3f5ea1731b9028b89b671cbd7e7d5e0421/src/util/virnetdevopenvswitch.c#L170

So no matter what external-id we add from os-vif, it is going to be lost when libvirt deletes the ovs port. Only those external-ids will survive that libvirt re-adds.

I see two possible ways:

1) Make this patch depend on Sean's https://review.opendev.org/602432. Because when the interface_type is ethernet, libvirt no longer deletes/re-adds the ovs port.

2) Or what this patch does: do not depend on Sean's patch, but add the trace info to some other place in ovsdb. Then of course when Sean's patch merges adapt and move the external-id to the port.

Please also have a look at the ovs-agent side: https://review.opendev.org/666610. Maybe some of the description there would be better placed here.

ok, it's (was) happening here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/602432/

But apart from this case, I keep my idea of storing this info in the interface.

mistral/db/v2/sqlalchemy/models.py.message: _get_nullable_column_names would be a bit more correct.
return [c.name for c in cls.__table__.columns if c.nullable]

It looks weird that we use "nones" and "nulls" at different places. Please make it consistent. Now I think that "nulls" is probably OK everywhere because "column.nullable" is something that we don't choose. This is part of SQLAlchemy.

The parameter "nulls" looks a bit weird here. In the previous version it was kind of OK because the method was in the upper layer where we had more context (i.e. "nulls" REST endpoint parameter). But here when you look at it it's hard to guess what it is. A list of None values?

My suggestion is "null_columns" or "empty_columns".

What's more, the name of the method "validate_nones" also looks weird now because it's in a different context. I'd suggest we use the following method signature:

def check_allowed_none_values(column_names):
    ...
These two methods are misplaced. They are 100% generic and can be applied to any DB model. So please move them to the most base class (model_base._MistralModelBase)

devstack/lib/cyborg.message:
This removes 'auth_section' with keystone_authtoken. But the standard docs, such as Red Hat [1], still refer to it. What is the impact of removing this?

[1] https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/15/html/users_and_identity_management_guide/application_credentials

auth_section causes the rest of the auth stuff to be ignored*, and instead grabs all the creds from the section named thereby. It's pretty evil and generally shouldn't be used. In a devstack setting it would be *okay*, but still more realistic and proper to set up the auth explicitly for each service.

(*...so if you _were_ going to use auth_section, you should really remove the rest of the auth opts, because they're not doing anything.)

Yes, thank you for excluding ceph from the "docker stop". Note how the ceph containers are managed by systemd below with Restart=always. If you docker stop then systemd will just start a new one.

[root@overcloud-cephstorage-2 ~]# vi /etc/systemd/system/ceph-osd\@.service
# Please do not change this file directly since it is managed by Ansible and will be overwritten
[Unit]
Description=Ceph OSD
After=docker.service

[Service]
EnvironmentFile=-/etc/environment
ExecStartPre=-/usr/bin/docker stop ceph-osd-overcloud-cephstorage-2-dev%i
ExecStartPre=-/usr/bin/docker rm -f ceph-osd-overcloud-cephstorage-2-dev%i
ExecStart=/usr/share/ceph-osd-run.sh %i
ExecStop=-/usr/bin/docker stop ceph-osd-overcloud-cephstorage-2-dev%i
Restart=always   # <---------------------------------------------------------- HERE!  
RestartSec=10s
TimeoutStartSec=120
TimeoutStopSec=15

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
[root@overcloud-cephstorage-2 ~]#

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What's odd is that the instance.availability_zone shouldn't really have anything to do with the reschedule since when we reschedule and conductor calls the scheduler for another host, it should be filtering on the user-requested availability zone from the RequestSpec, not what is set on the instance.

I guess the issue is really that the RequestSpec is not passed from compute to conductor on reschedule (that was added in Queens Ie5233bd481013413f12e55201588d37a9688ae78) and without that we build the request spec from the instance:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/pike/nova/conductor/manager.py#L547

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6e2ec5c5a397b508cddb646e865b6f4d2132f1d6/nova/objects/request_spec.py#L156

So that's really the issue and why nulling out the instance.AZ in compute affects the RequestSpec in conductor during reschedule.

So yes https://review.opendev.org/#/c/606161/ helps, but so would Ie5233bd481013413f12e55201588d37a9688ae78.

Note that with either of those Queens changes, if RPC API versions are pinned we'd still have the same issue because conductor wouldn't get the request_spec or host_list parameters.

I think a note about taking care wrt. the number of machines being shut down at a time.

By default the Ceph CRUSH map is configured to treat each individual machine in the cloud as a failure domain.

The default pool configuration is to replicate the data across three failure domains, and require at least two of them to be present to accept writes.

If you shut down more than one machine at a time you could risk making two of three copies of a particular placement group unavailable, which in turn would make consuming applications block on writes until the copies are available again.

The Ceph CRUSH map can be configured to spread replicas over a different failure domain than machines.
Done

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Stack this on top of the --amend patch.

Do we like this syntax? Other options:

- Break compat and make `set` append and add `unset` to remove. Both would work with --trait (repeatable). Cons: breaks compat; can't add & remove in a single operation (which is probably fine).
- New `add` and `remove` commands.
- Some form of ... trait set --append $NAME and --remove $NAME (both repeatable). --add-trait/--remove-trait? These would have to be mutually exclusive with --trait, which is a bit ick.

Compared to some other OSC commands like server set with --property:

https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/server.html#server-set

The --amend thing is different since with server set --property you don't have to specify --amend (nor is server set a full replacement of the metadata).

To remove server metadata, you have to use server unset --property:

https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/server.html#server-unset

That's different from how port tags are done:

https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/port.html#port-set

For that one, you can add tags using --tag, --no-tag to remove all tags, and combine them to replace all tags. And you can use port unset --tag to remove a single tag:

https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/port.html#port-unset

Or port unset --all-tag to remove all tags.

So if you did just --no-trait to remove a single trait rather than all, it would not jive with the port set command. Consistency with this stuff is hard, especially since we don't have a resource provider trait unset command (but we could add one).

What would happen if I did resource provider trait set --no-trait without --amend? I'm assuming it would just remove all traits right? Similar to port set --no-tag.
is this okay, or should we make an attempt to validate that what you're trying to add/remove doesn't/does already exist on the provider?

I don't think we need to do validation client-side for that, e.g. if I want to remove CUSTOM_FOO and that trait isn't on the provider, then who cares - it's already in the state I want. The client should probably validate, however, that the set of --trait(s) and --no-trait(s) are mutually exclusive.
Is this okay? It probably means a typo. Should we try to check?
I think the same as above - if I want to remove X and X doesn't exist already, it's fine - things are already in the state I want them in.

Actually, ignore my "let compute manager handle support" comment. I forgot rescue is a cast. I still think:

 1. We probably don't need a check for a conflict between stable support and the image keys because the user isn't in control
 2. If we have that check, we could gate the fatality on a version check instead
 3. I do think a trait/flag for "can rescue BFV instances" makes sense

If you take my combo of 1 and 3, we'd have one trait for the BFV case, and no safety check if the operator has configured a rescue image with the not-honorable image keys in it for the transient case. Since those keys are already present since Ocata, they could have them on images now with no impact (AFAIK) so suddenly breaking on that for un-updated computes would be kinda weird.

Speaking of that, what happens if you're using hyperv or vmware and you rescue with an image using those properties? Will we fail the rescue because essentially we can't honor the contract from the image metadata so the results of the rescue might not be what the user expected? Or are we just going to silently ignore them in the other virt drivers?

However, then you get different behaviors depending on which hypervisor driver your VM is running on, right? I mean, I guess that's going to be the case with this spec anyway because if you rescue with an image using those properties but your VM is not running on the libvirt driver, the image properties aren't going to be honored.

Well, other virt driver maintainers that already support rescue in their driver would want to consider adding support for the image properties, right? Just wondering about the case mentioned above where those non-libvirt drivers get an image with the properties but they don't support them.

So if my server is running on a Train compute but the control plane is Ussuri and doing rolling upgrades, if I try to rescue with the image using those properties, it's not going to work as I expected. Any consideration for minimum compute service version checks when rescuing with an image that has those properties?

True they have been around albeit undocumented so I don't think anyone would know to use them. To be clear, I'm not -1 because I think we need to be super strict about upgrade impacts here with checking service versions and such, but I think it's worth calling out in the spec as a thing we're consciously not going to do and why for if/when it comes up later at some point.

That's really what my -1 is about: documenting the responses to the things I've mentioned, like ignoring the properties for the other drivers above (if we do that), in case it comes up later.

These properties have been around since ocata. So today you can rescue with those properties set to something and they're just ignored. I think that just starting to honor them when we can is fine, no?
